dict.string: Consonant cluster
A phenomenon of sound change when two consonants continue together.
Devoicing
A phenonmenon where a voiced sound becomes unvoiced (doesn't make the throat vibrate).
Unreleased stop
A phonemenon where breath release is left out when two or more stops continue together.
Nasa release
A phenomenon where the breath relase for /t/ and /d/ is left out and the breath escapes through the nose.
Lateral release
A phenomenon where the breath relase for /t/ and /d/ is left out and the breath escapes form both sides of the tongue.
Assimilation
A phenomenon where one of two sounds resembles the other when they continue together.
Elison
A phenomenon of elision in fast, casual speak.
Reduction
A phenomenon where function words (prepositions, auxiliaries, etc.) take their weak from.
Aspiration
A phenomenon where a strong breath sound is made in the space moving from a voiceless stop to vowel.
Stop
Speech sounds produced with a sudden release of air pressure made with the tongue and libs.
Fricative
Speech sounds produced by forcing the air through a narrow channel made with the tongue and lips.
Nasal
Speech sounds produced by blocking the air with the tongue and libs so that it escapes through the nose as it does in humming.
Lateral
Speech sounds produced by the air proceeding along the sides of the tongue as it is being blocked by the tongue from going through the middle of the mouth.
Semi-vowel
Speech sounds produced by the transition from a vowel-like sound created with a particular shape of the mouth or the tongue to a subsequent vowel.
Short-vowel
Relatively short vowels produced with the tongue ofen relaxed.
Long-vowel
Relatively long vowels produced with the tonque ofen tensed.
Diphthong
Vowels produced by the combination of two different types of vowels
